abstract: A look at the aftermath of the storm through the eyes of three women.
lead_paragraph: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.

headline: Happy New Year
abstract: We wish you a happy and healthy 2022. Below, a look at some unusual New Year’s Eves.
lead_paragraph: David Carr, the late Times columnist and media critic, starred in videos years ago that were shot in Times Square. At the end of them, he cheerily said: “They call it Times Square for a reason.”

headline: Paris reintroduces an outdoor mask mandate.
abstract: With more than 2,000 coronavirus cases per 100,000 people, the capital has become the center of France’s spreading Omicron outbreak.
lead_paragraph: A new mandate to wear masks outdoors took effect on Friday in Paris as part of an effort to slow down the spread of the Omicron variant in the French capital, which has become the center of the country’s latest wave of coronavirus infections.

headline: Colorado Wildfires: What We Know
abstract: The fires on Thursday burned at least 500 homes and forced tens of thousands of residents to evacuate.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage as officials asses damage of Colorado wildfires

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: Our newest picks include a good cop-bad cop revenge thriller starring Donnie Yen, a high-tech animated take on Hansel and Gretel, and more.
lead_paragraph: For action fans seeking out new movies on streaming, there are plenty of car chases, explosions and fist fights to sift through. We help by providing some streaming highlights.

headline: Another Covid Winter, but Our Quarantine Comforts No Longer Work
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'New Year', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: Americans have spared little expense over the past two years turning their homes into cozy havens. That doesn’t mean they want to spend another winter in them.
lead_paragraph: Scott Haas has had enough of the four houseplants he bought in 2020 as his version of the pandemic puppy — living things that he could nurture through his isolation. But that was back when he thought the pandemic had an end date and he wanted to make his home office feel homier. Now, Mr. Haas, the author of “Why Be Happy? The Japanese Way of Acceptance,” can barely look at the plants.

headline: How We Make Sense of Time
keywords: ['New Year', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Seasons and Months', 'Physics', 'Rosh Hashana', 'Lunar New Year', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Philosophy']
abstract: January 2022 arrives as our methods of keeping time feel like they are breaking. Calendar pages turn, yet time feels lost. In this year of all years, what does it mean for a year to be new?
lead_paragraph: Deep inside a mountain in West Texas, Alexander Rose has been working to build a clock with a pendulum that will tick for 10,000 years.

headline: A Daughter’s Reclamation of Her Father’s Past
abstract: The artist Sadie Barnette shares a new work that reframes pages from the dossier the F.B.I. kept on her parent, the founder of the Compton chapter of the Black Panthers.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-seen work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at “FBI Drawings: Unknown” (2021), a diptych done in powdered graphite and colored pencil by Sadie Barnette. Known for incisive, labor-intensive prints and installations, she reimagines her familial history in her latest show, “Sadie Barnette: Inheritance,” on view at Jessica Silverman Gallery in San Francisco until Jan. 8, 2022.

headline: ‘Buy Now, Pay Later’ Loans May Soon Play Bigger Role in Credit Scores
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Credit Scores', 'Credit and Debt', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Content Type: Service', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The credit-rating companies argue that reporting of on-time payments can help shoppers build a credit history. But consumer experts note that late or missed payments can hurt.
lead_paragraph: “Buy now, pay later” online loans are getting attention from both regulators and the credit industry as consumers increasingly turn to them, and they may soon play a bigger role in credit scores.

headline: In a New Series, ‘Around the World in 80 Days’ Gets More Worldly
abstract: The latest take on the classic Jules Verne novel, for PBS’s Masterpiece, expands on earlier adaptations with new characters and a more diverse cast.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN, South Africa — David Tennant, sitting in a wicker chair in the large, empty garden of a grand hotel here, gestured at its pink pillared veranda. “An appropriate setting!” he said, alluding to the colonial era architecture and his role in “Around the World in 80 Days,” a new television series based on the 1872 novel by Jules Verne.

headline: Clifton Collins Jr. Hopes ‘Jockey’ Makes a Familiar Face a Familiar Name, Too
abstract: You know the actor from countless TV shows, but after immersive preparation for a rare leading role, he appears headed for a breakthrough.
lead_paragraph: Every time Clifton Collins Jr. boards a flight midproduction, the possibility of the aircraft crashing petrifies him. “I’ve got to finish the film,” the actor thinks to himself midair.

headline: In Remembering Tutu, South Africa Reckons With Lasting Challenges
abstract: Archbishop Desmond Tutu’s death has reignited a public conversation about the state of the country’s reconciliation process and its democracy.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — In a requiem Mass that interwove several southern African languages, in the style of Archbishop Desmond Tutu’s own preaching, parishioners at his former church in Johannesburg bade farewell this week to the activist priest who took on apartheid with a message of peace and forgiveness.

headline: Asma Khader, Fighter for Women’s Rights in Jordan, Dies at 69
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Politics and Government', "Women's Rights", 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: A respected lawyer, she focused on the victims of domestic violence and also worked hard to change discriminatory laws.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Asma Khader, an internationally recognized advocate for human rights and one of Jordan’s leading campaigners for the rights of women and girls, especially the victims of domestic violence, died here on Dec. 20. She was 69.

headline: 15 Songs We Almost Missed This Year
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Folk Music', 'Jazz', 'Two Thousand Twenty One']
abstract: Hear tracks by Sofia Kourtesis, Remble, Caetano Veloso and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: How many books make a place feel like home? Also in this edition: a marijuana boom in Oklahoma, and Nikki Giovanni on making peace with her hate.
lead_paragraph: How many books make a place feel like home? Also in this edition: a marijuana boom in Oklahoma, and Nikki Giovanni on making peace with her hate.

headline: Recipes for New Year’s Eve
abstract: Put together a Dutch baby with bacon and Camembert, to eat with a glass of something bubbly.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Greetings from isolation on this final day of what was for many an unsettling, un-fun year. There’ll be no Champagne and caviar for me tonight, no elegant roast, no countdown to 2022. I might tie some flies, listen to an old Ry Cooder show. Quarantine and testing, here’s to auld lang syne.

headline: Sometimes You Have to Hate Exercise Before You Can Love It Again
abstract: When my partner, Oliver Sacks, died, I lost interest in working out. But I found my way back.
lead_paragraph: Another January is upon us, and with your holiday feasting over, you might be hearing the voice of an invisible trainer in your head, telling you to hit the gym, the pool, the track or the hiking trail, and hit it fast. But the guilt we may feel about putting it off is usually a waste of time. We need rest, too.

headline: The Day the Soviet Flag Came Down
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'War and Armed Conflicts', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Reflections on the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 25, 1991, at 7:32 p.m., the Soviet flag came down over the Kremlin, and the pre-Revolutionary Russian flag of white, blue and red horizontal stripes took its place. It was a momentous moment, but witnessed by only a handful of foreigners and an irate Soviet war veteran on Red Square.

headline: Scenes From a World on Fire
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (2021)', 'Coal', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Weather', 'Solar Energy']
abstract: Climate change is already here. It’s just not evenly distributed yet.
lead_paragraph: Planet Earth is the one thing that all humans share. We are often at its mercy. We take its majesty for granted. We forget that we merely hold it in trust for our children’s children, for all those who’ll come after us.

headline: Studies Suggest Why Omicron Is Less Severe: It Spares the Lungs
abstract: Compared with earlier variants, Omicron may cause less damage to the lungs, new animal research suggests.
lead_paragraph: A spate of new studies on lab animals and human tissues are providing the first indication of why the Omicron variant causes milder disease than previous versions of the coronavirus.

headline: Virginia Sues Town of Windsor, Accusing It of Discriminatory Policing
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Attorneys General', 'Racial Profiling', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The suit comes after a monthslong investigation, which Attorney General Mark Herring said uncovered a pattern of “discriminatory, unconstitutional policing.”
lead_paragraph: Virginia’s attorney general filed a lawsuit on Thursday against the town of Windsor, seeking changes in policing and saying that his office’s monthslong investigation uncovered evidence of discriminatory, unconstitutional policing.

headline: The Secrets to Successful Aging in 2022
abstract: Advice from Well’s most popular stories of the year.
lead_paragraph: Looking for ways to grow old gracefully? Over the past year, Well’s columnists have reported on how to keep your mind and body healthy over time. Here are some of their top insights from the most popular stories published in 2021.

headline: Aiding Afghan Refugees in the U.S.
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: Readers discuss hosting an Afghan family, urge helping needy Americans first and suggest a G.I. Bill for Afghans. Also: Is the Supreme Court partisan?
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Decision Looms That Could Determine Fate of Alzheimer’s Drug
abstract: Medicare officials are trying to determine whether to cover Aduhelm, which the F.D.A. approved despite unclear evidence that it helps patients.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials are wrestling with a decision that could go a long way toward determining the future of the controversial new Alzheimer’s drug, Aduhelm, and whether significant numbers of patients use it.

headline: Why Did Uganda Send Troops Into Congo?
abstract: The Ugandan government says it is targeting rebels it accuses of terrorist attacks in Kampala. Many Congolese fear the incursion is cover for yet another plundering of their country.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — It has been a month since Uganda began air and artillery strikes in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, and then sent in its troops, in an operation targeting a rebel group it accuses of carrying out a string of deadly attacks in the Ugandan capital, Kampala.

headline: Once a Janitor, Now the Bar Mitzvah Photography King of Montreal
abstract: With a touch of chutzpah and “a little help from God,” Braulio Rocha, a Roman Catholic Portuguese immigrant, traded in his mop for a camera.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Braulio Rocha, a Portuguese janitor at a Montreal synagogue, was about to begin his daily floor mopping routine some years ago when he heard a frantic voice: The photographer assigned to shoot a bris, a ritual circumcision, hadn’t shown up, and the baby’s grandmother was panicking.

headline: China’s Ban on ‘Sissy Men’ Is Bound to Backfire
abstract: The masculinity campaign is a way for the  Chinese Communist Party to distract from its inability to address economic and social issues.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China is facing serious challenges on multiple fronts: Great power competition with the United States. Trade disputes. The future of Taiwan. But that doesn’t mean it’s too preoccupied to escalate a battle of another sort on the home front.

headline: Leadership Advice from the Coach of America’s ‘Worst’ Hockey Team
abstract: John Bacon played for the Ann Arbor Huron High School River Rats when they were good. Coaching them when they were dreadful was far more satisfying.
lead_paragraph: John Bacon got more satisfaction from coaching a bad hockey team than he did playing for a good one. In his new book, “Let Them Lead: Unexpected Lessons in Leadership from America’s Worst High School Hockey Team,” Bacon, a journalist and leadership consultant, explores why and what made the difference.

headline: Under the Radar Theater Festival Canceled as Omicron Surges
abstract: Putting off the Public Theater’s annual showcase for experimental work was the latest sign of the variant’s impact on live performance.
lead_paragraph: As a surge of coronavirus cases driven by the Omicron variant takes a growing toll on live performance, the Public Theater on Friday announced it would cancel its Under the Radar festival, originally scheduled to begin on Jan. 12.

headline: Earthy Mushrooms, Bold Peppers
abstract: Start 2022 with big flavors.
lead_paragraph: Hello, Five Weeknight Dishers. This is Krysten, stepping in for Emily. (Close watchers of this space will remember me as this newsletter’s editor!)

headline: People with Omicron are less likely to need hospitalization, U.K. report finds.
abstract: The findings represent some of the largest sets of real-world data to be released since the highly contagious variant was first discovered.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — People who contracted the Omicron variant of the coronavirus were about half as likely to need hospital care as those infected with the Delta variant, and one-third as likely to need emergency care, according to a report issued on Friday by British health officials.

headline: Russian Foreign Minister Levels New Warning on Ukraine
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government', 'War and Armed Conflicts', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Sergey V. Lavrov accused the United States and its allies of stoking a conflict in the country’s east in comments that contrasted with a more positive tone coming from Moscow.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, warned on Friday that the Kremlin perceives the United States and its allies as stoking the war in eastern Ukraine, a shift in tone from Moscow just hours after another Russian official had said the Kremlin was satisfied with a phone call between the leaders of the two countries.

headline: A New Year and a New Leader, but Germany’s Focus Remains on Covid
abstract: Olaf Scholz, who replaced Angela Merkel as chancellor about three weeks ago, gave the traditional New Year’s Eve address for the first time and called for unity and vaccinations.
lead_paragraph: HANOVER, Germany — There was a new face delivering the chancellor’s New Year’s Eve address, but for Covid-weary Germans, the focus was all too familiar.

headline: Quebec government faces backlash over New Year’s Eve curfew.
abstract: Residents who leave their homes past 10 p.m. could face fines of up to $4,750.
lead_paragraph: New Year’s Eve was canceled in Quebec, or at least that’s how many residents feel after the government imposed a 10 p.m. curfew that will go into effect on Friday night, just as the revelry was set to begin.

headline: The Times Square celebration will be muted. The police presence will not.
lead_paragraph: New York City prepared on Friday to welcome a new year with a heavily edited version of its traditional Times Square celebration.

headline: Sam Jones, Sharpshooting Celtics Star of the 1960s, Dies at 88
abstract: A member of the Basketball Hall of Fame, he was named one of the 50 greatest players in N.B.A. history and played on 10 N.B.A. championship teams.
lead_paragraph: Sam Jones, the Boston Celtics’ sharpshooting Hall of Fame guard who played on 10 N.B.A. championship teams, a milestone exceeded only by his teammate Bill Russell, died on Thursday in Florida. He was 88.

headline: Omicron is overwhelming New York’s quarantine hotel system.
abstract: People are waiting for rooms for days. At a homeless shelter in Brooklyn, 11 women with Covid were crammed into a single room.
lead_paragraph: For much of the pandemic, one way New York City has tried to slow the coronavirus’s spread is by offering free hotel rooms to infected people who cannot easily isolate themselves from those they live with.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in January
abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of January’s most promising new titles.
lead_paragraph: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: Betty White, a TV Fixture for Seven Decades, Is Dead at 99
abstract: Among the many highlights of a career that began in 1949 were star turns on “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” in the 1970s and “Saturday Night Live” in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Betty White, who created two of the most memorable characters in sitcom history, the nymphomaniacal Sue Ann Nivens on “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” and the sweet but dim Rose Nylund on “The Golden Girls” — and who capped her long career with a comeback that included a triumphant appearance as the host of “Saturday Night Live” at the age of 88 — died on Friday. She was 99.

headline: Vikings quarterback Kirk Cousins tests positive in latest blow to the N.F.L. postseason race.
abstract: Cousins was placed on the team’s Covid-19 reserve list for at least five days, threatening Minnesota’s playoff chances.
lead_paragraph: Two days before the Minnesota Vikings face one of the best teams in the N.F.L., quarterback Kirk Cousins tested positive for the coronavirus and was placed on the team’s Covid-19 reserve list, a move that will sideline him for at least five days.

headline: What It’s Like to Leave Prison During a Pandemic
abstract: For most people, patching together a life after prison is a daunting task. Even getting an ID can be tricky. We spent a year with Richard, Genisis and Mychal as they navigated the transition from cell to home.
lead_paragraph: For most people, patching together a life after prison is a daunting task. Even getting an ID can be tricky. We spent a year with Richard, Genisis and Mychal as they navigated the transition from cell to home.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
abstract: Look back, look ahead.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. It’s New Year’s Eve and Omicron has put the brakes on any socially proximate revelry we may have had planned. We’re old pros by now at re-envisioning holidays — we’re old pros at re-envisioning any day, truth be told.

headline: Public university students in New York must now get vaccine boosters.
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul unveiled the measure as the fast-spreading Omicron variant continued to push the number of virus cases in the state to new heights with each passing day.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 600,000 public university students in New York will soon be required to get vaccination booster shots as part of the state’s stepped-up effort to combat a record-breaking coronavirus outbreak, Gov. Kathy Hochul announced on Friday.
